titleStmt.title: M54, 6 of 11. [Anon: the pear shaped lute; on which the Queen herself once played...]. Typescript fragment, 1 fol.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 6 of 11. [the pear shaped lute; on which the Queen herself once played...]. Typescript fragment, 1 fol.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: the pear shaped lute; on which the herself once played But the Elizabethans themselves are silent. Only their furni (furniture) remains, stiff, ornate, fasntastic (fantastic) and uncushioned; and the vardibgalls (vardingales) which roused the preachers wrath.

xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmy wxmxmxmxmxmxmx The Elizabthans (Elizabethans) are unknonw (unknown) to us because when they write rpose (prose) txxxx the rhytm (rhythm) of the Bible was in their ears. Its ia (It is a) garemt (garment) only to be worn when the mind is in the right attidt de (attitude). It crushes out the simple, the sublte (subtle), the breif (brief). Their letters are state
documnets (documents), intricate, involved, circum locutious (circumlocutions). There is no gaiety, no freedom, no warmth in the great room. When Lady writes to , she admonishes, she exhosrts (exhorts). Greek and atin (Latin) come as easily to her pen as a French phrase would come to ours. If she has to decsned (descend) to an actual o jsc t (object)-- a basket of strwberries (strawberries)-- it w is w -th (with) dark insintuations (insinuations). Fear of God and suspcicion (suspicion) of man surround her as with the walls of a dungeon. The wall may conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and gay; it must conceal laughter, love, good humour, and all the trifles of daily life. But behind that stiff garment of Elizabethan prose who can tell what emotions are alive? They are
pomous (pompous); they are solmen (solemn); they are longwinded; We lknow (know) nothing about the audience who saw the plays acted; we know notning (nothing) about the public who had the books read aloud to them.
